b"There is, unfortunately, a sort of ''buyer beware' with therapy, in that it may well leave you feeling worse initially before it gets better. My therapist did warn me of that at the start of mine, but me being me, it took about 18 months before i really started opening up and talking about stuff, so for me the last year was really hard. It does get better though. I think there's a point where old defences and coping mechanisms are kinda being opened up and dismantled a bit, but the new ways of managing aren't quite concrete enough, so there is a period where you feel all over the place. My therapist said it's part of the process, and a sign that real change is happening. It's not unusual at all, and decent therapists should know about it, warn you about it, and be able to keep you safe while the therapy is happening - i.e by not rushing things and being able to handle whatever you tell them, and be able to 'contain' you and your emotions during the process. Can you contact your therapist in between sessions if you need to? I know you've only had the first one, but when things got really tricky for me, my therapist said i could call her if i was feeling wobbly. I did it twice, and it really helped. I know they don't generally like to encourage that (contact in between sessions) but sometimes it is appropriate. Could you tell your therapist in the next session how you've been feeling in between? It might get them to slow down a bit and take it a bit more gently - they shouldn't really push you too hard at the start as they need to see where you're at and build the relationship. Hang in there KS, it will be ok."
